nodepool/driver/openstack/config.py.message:
I think that this 255 characters is still (partly) the case?  It's all so long ago ...

But I think that nova used to enforce these limits, and over the years of API movement it has been passed of to glance directly.

I think that the original check was removed with Ibec92e278887cd06e91687ca91e75f9b7b28098c which used to be in the create_image() path and enforced 255 for the property and value

https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/image/v2/index.html?expanded=create-image-detail#request still says

"Additionally, you may include additional properties specified as key:value pairs, where the value must be a string data type. Keys are limited to 255 chars in length."

So maybe the value part is irrelevant, but the key length checking is still valid?

It's unclear from the documentation if the 255 limit is for both the key and the value combined, or the key and value separately; FWIW I'd prefer to just pass it to glance and let it deal with the validation instead of try to second guess it (even on the length), if that's OK with you.
This appears to have been commented out with code movement in I3d1ae0f0a6cc6675169974dd1beece8429071a49.  I do not think that was intentional

overall my minor concern here is that previously if you had a long key (and maybe value) it would be ignored here, and things would be working.  once we gave an error -- per the prior comment it seems we're not even giving that now -- but it was then ignored.

There is a *minuscule* chance that this breaks something that was working.  We should probably just call out explicitly in the changelog "previously metadata was checked in nodepool and invalid values would be silently ignored, now it will be passed to the image service directly and cause an API error" or similar.

releasenotes/notes/remove-diskimage-meta.message: I guess Ian's prior question is whether Glance will actually return an error vs silently discarding the non-conforming entries (but the prior implementation in Nodepool was silently discarding them, so I'm not sure that's effectively a regression even if so).

Yeah I think that it will reject any keys that are > 255 with appropriate http errors; before they would have been filtered here.  given how unlikely this is to actually cause anyone a regression, just the comment seems sufficient.

nodepool/zk/components.py.message: As noted elsewhere in my review I think having pools treated as launchers when we have a separate launcher component (this one) is confusing. Is this component even used? We should probably try to be more consistent to avoid confusion later.

This isn't necessary for this change, nor is the builder.  I'm trying to set us up for being able to actually have a view of the whole system like we do with Zuul.

Nodepool itself only needs to care about the pool workers (which have been misleadingly called "launchers" up to this point).  If we want to have all the procesess represented, then we need to have something registered for the "nodepool-launcher" command.  I think *that* should be called a launcher.  So yes, this change starts calling the pool workers within the launchers pools, but doesn't change all of the code in nodepool to use different variable names.

I am trying to set us up for avoiding confusion later.  The best way I know to do that is to call launchers launchers, and pools pools.
What determines this? It seems that BaseComponent.__setattr__ doesn't check/prevent updates.
Does this include the sequence identifier? It must because we don't seem to handle a sequence otherwise.
The "hostname" is the ZK path component which includes the sequence id.

I feel like we discussed this when zuul added model api versioning, but I find this particular case to be confusing. If on startup we hit this condition we exit(1) to prevent data corruption. But if it occurs after we've set self.model_api we'll fast forward our local version ahead of our MODEL_API after we hit this case? That doesn't seem correct.

This is copied from Zuul to achieve parity.

This could only happen if our registration was somehow dropped (since if our version is lower than the rest, we should be the ones setting the minimum).

If we're having trouble with ZK such that this happens, it's arguable whether it's better to just resume as before or exit because someone might have been tricked into doing an upgrade that needs to be rolled back.

My inclination is to avoid exiting here because it could lead to a minor ZK hiccup causing the whole system to exit.  But I don't think there's a clear right answer.

I was confusing. Sorry. Let me try again:

Old behavior:
No AZ -> AZ => pin to the new AZ (1)

New behavior:
No AZ -> AZ => move to the new AZ but do not pin to the new AZ. (2)
AZ1 -> AZ2 => move to the new AZ2 and pin to AZ2. (3)

* So (1) and (2) means the new behavior will be different from the old one
* Also (2) and (3) are not symmetric in both case you provide a new AZ but in (2) you are not pinned to the new AZ while in (3) you are pinned to the new AZ.

It becomes tricky regarding the client. We have three mutually exclusive parameters --availability-zone, --host, --unpin-az.
--unpin-az is to avoid problems with the string type if --availability-zone="None"
A user could want to unpin and move to an AZ.
Here we have a problem if --unpin-az is used with --availability-zone as this is currently impossible.

So instead of only removing the mutually exclusive, I would be more in favor of adding a new API parameter regarding the az constraint.
So it will "decouple" the notion of AZ constraint and AZ location.
It will also add the possibility to pin/unpin the az of an instance. (pin is missing today)
Although this is a more significant change in the spec and code, still doable, I think.

@Sylvain: I'm OK with your comments / suggestions in the pad
After Sean pointed out on IRC that we should decouple the effect of host from AZ (as we do that during boot too) I proposed a new table https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/unshelve-to-host#L166

> AZ being unset and AZ being set to None are two different cases. 

/o\ you are right. Then we have to make a bit bigger table to consider all 6 request in all possible start state X:

X -> AZ + host
X -> AZ + no host
X -> AZ=None + host
X -> AZ=None + no host
X -> No AZ + host /no host
X -> No AZ + no host

Gibi note also the pb on the client explain in my previous comment. I think adding a param for AZ constraint will give also the opportunity to pin an instance.

So the table could be:

```
boot az  | az  | host | az constraint | Behavior
----------------------------------------------------------------------
no       | no  | no   | no            | unshelve to any host
no       | no  | no   | az            | invalid
no       | no  | no   | None          | invalid not pinned
no       | no  | host | no            | unshelve to host rs=None
no       | no  | host | az            | unshelve to host rs=az if h in az
no       | no  | host | None          | invalid not pinned
no       | az  | no   | no            | unshelve to az, rs=none
no       | az  | no   | az            | unshelve to az, rs=az if az same
no       | az  | no   | None          | invalid not pinned
no       | az  | host | no            | unshelve to host rs=none if h in az
no       | az  | host | az            | unshelve to host rs=az if h in az + az same
no       | az  | host | None          | invalid not pinned

azb      | no  | no   | no            | unshelve to any host in azb
azb      | no  | no   | az            | invalid
azb      | no  | no   | None          | unshelve to any host rs=None *unpin
azb      | no  | host | no            | unshelve to host if h in azb
azb      | no  | host | az            | unshelve to host if h in az rs=az
azb      | no  | host | None          | unshelve to host rs=none *unpin
azb      | az  | no   | no            | invalid pinned to azb
azb      | az  | no   | az            | unshelve to az and rs=az if az same
azb      | az  | no   | None          | unshelve to az, rs=none *unpin
azb      | az  | host | no            | unshelve to host if az=azb and h in azb
azb      | az  | host | az            | unshelve to host rs=az if h in az
azb      | az  | host | None          | unshelve to host rs=None if h in az
```

For now I ignored the additional API parameter (AZ constraint) proposed by Uggla above as we might not need it. And just went ahead and update the current table but also considering the difference between no AZ and AZ=None in the unshelve request. And also adding support for AZ=AZ1 host=host1 in the unshelve request (if host1 in AZ1). And also flipping over the problematic no AZ => AZ case as a response to Dan's comment:

> I agree, it's very confusing to sometimes provide an AZ and pin and other times not. That seems like something we should avoid."

Please see https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/unshelve-to-host#L102

> This is probably okay, but.. is it necessary? Seems like as long as the AZ and host match, we should allow them to unshelve and pin the thing to the AZ of the host we chose, no?

Based on the current proposal this change would add these three new rules:
* Any -> AZ + host => if host is not in AZ then reject
* No AZ -> AZ + host => if host is in AZ then move to host but do not pin to AZ
* AZ1 -> AZ2 + host => if host is in AZ2 then move to host and pin to AZ2

Is this what you are after?

> Also, why not allow AZ=None,host=$host in case I want to put it somewhere but have it not be tied to the original AZ. This is less important/useful, but as a user I probably won't understand why you won't let me do this.

The current proposal already has:
* No AZ -> No AZ but host => move to host but not pin to any AZ 
* AZ ->  No AZ but host => move to host and re-pin to the AZ of the new host

Do you suggest to keep the first but change the second rule not to re-pin?

Captured my thoughts on both IRC and the etherpad. I think we reached a consensus, my only concern is making sure we don't persist the AZ change if we could end up with a NoValidHosts due a wrong (AZ, host) tuple.

specs/zed/decouple-tripleo-tasks.rst.message:
+1, makes sense to have separate workflows for scale-out and overcloud (re)configuration for one or more services. But it's probably difficult to know what services are impacted by a THT parameter/resource mapping change beforehand.

Also, I've seen users wanting to run 'only' certain steps (ex. post_deploy) or restart from a failed step. If we can make --start-at-task work for most of these scenarios so that they don't have to re-run all the playbooks it would be  good.

Yes, users will need some knowledge of how things work internally in order to be able to reason about what all might be required for a change to take effect. I will add something about that in the operator impact section. Hopefully, the breakout into native ansible (instead of all the generation with config-download) will help make this more obvious.

This should probably also include running update_tasks on the new nodes to ensure that any new packages are deployed immediately. There has been some discussion recently about how a scaled-up node and an updated node look different and should be the same.

The primary complaint from customers appears to be that the package versions don't match, so simply ensuring that there's a dnf update included on the node in the scale-up should solve the issue.

If existing nodes aren't up to the same level, that's a different problem. In the case for these customers the issue is that the overcloud image has packages which date older than the packages available in the satellite... and doing a post-scale-up update extends the run time of the operation significantly, even with the limit applied.

How would you design this to work?
We already have overcloud update with --limit, would that match what you're describing?

I don't think we would want to run update automatically as part of scale up, existing nodes might not be updated yet either.
understanding/ or "The upgrade workflow includes a full re-execution of the ``deploy_steps_playbook`` "
Done

this kind of sound like the task stucture used by kolla ansibel although a little more complicated.

https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/tree/master/ansible/roles/keystone/tasks
https://github.com/openstack/kolla-ansible/blob/master/doc/source/contributor/adding-a-new-service.rst

each service si a role
each role has a task per high level operation like generating configs.

the task files a a predicatbel name scheme and hihgh level playbooks compose the task.

confirugtion is doen via 2 mechaniusme the inventory file and a hihg level gobal.yaml that is sourced via the kolla-ansbile cli via -e @/etc/kolla/global.yaml when invoking the top level playbook.

they have one quirck which si they use an action varable to determin which task playbook to include from there roles main.yaml but that is a small detail.

perhaps we coudl draw inseration form them in desgining
Ack, i'll take a look

I think we should specify that the any "initial" tasks and docker config should still be implemented in a way to make them idempotent (re-executable at any time without breaking the world). So that skipping them in later operations would be a performance optimization but not a must.

There might be various edge cases when re-executing them could be helpful, e.g. troubleshooting and trying to "re-assert" the state of the overcloud, recovering from a failed deploy operation, or adding a new service to an existing cloud.
thanks, I added a note about idempotency.

+1 all our roles shodul be idempotent however that does not mean they take 0 time.

kolla has a spereate  bootstrap-servers  command which runs jsut the host bootstrap playbook

this is responible for all host configurtion including installing docker ectra.

i think it would make sense to have bootsraping the hosts onto which the overcloud will be deploy a seperate command for a tripleo client perspective.


and on the ansibel side it shoudl be a seperate top level playbook.

i shoudl also not that bootstrap-servers intentionlaly starts after the host os has been isntalled.


the kolla approch is deploy-servers, bootstrap-servers then deploy openstack.

that split allows a clean seperation of concerns and woudl allow triplo to reuse the bootstrap-servers palybook for preprovisioned servers or triplo povisioned servers as all it would assume is ssh access to the host and it woudl be responceable for boot straping the host form that point such that docker/podman and any other services/tools required for ooo to deploy openstack are installed and configurd before the main deployment of openstack happens.

also I think initial_ is redundant here

i've actually redefined the list of management interfaces based off of the linked POC in the References section, so please take another look.

* The composition would happen via Ansible's `include_tasks` or `import_tasks` modules i guess? (Rather than on Heat level?)

* How would external_deploy_tasks fit the picture here though? They target a different host (undercloud), so IIUC they can't be included as tasks into any of the new role_data keys. The external deploy steps would have to still be interleaved on playbook level (separate play with different `hosts`) rather than task list level i think?

take a look at how I'm defining the broken out playbooks in the POC. these still allow us to target a source host and target hosts (undercloud/overcloud) as needed.

I think the POC will help define a lot of how this ends up looking, and I plan to refine the spec as it plays out.

good point. Scale-out up/down requires targeting nodes groups. Only playbooks can do that, not roles, nor tasks. I propose to add the following:

There should be roles for each service with tasks that cover deploy, upgrade, update. Playbooks will substitute today tripleo composable roles t-h-t based paradigm, and also will cover scale-out up/down (as roles do not target groups of hosts, but only playbooks). The shipped/packaged content would represent a starting point for standard roles, and users are supposed to edit it as their custom roles require that.

that would likely be not an instant change. Let's describe how would we switch things from puppet to ansible gradually. How would we extract and transfer config some of the management bits, while keeping the other ones still managed with puppet? (merging configs, like with --config-dir, should help)
would be nice to describe these shortly

neutron_vpnaas/extensions/vpnaas.py.message:
technically speaking this is an API change. The way this is done is problematic for a couple of reasons:

a) it can't be discovered whether or not a neutron server does or not support such mode.
b) if a client is successful in creating an IKE session in aggressive mode, backends that not support it will fail to honor the request silently (as Yamamoto pointed out).

We should address a) and b) to move forward, IMO

specs/zed/approved/glance/expanding-stor.message: we do have filesystem_store_dirs as well

nit: give a new line above line 28 for better readability

This by definition has impact to the API right? 😊

Could we have example data structures that we're expecting to see here?
Ack, makes sense, no harm in documenting the API response

Yeah, I do think that's an API impact, because you just wrote a good paragraph explaining the impact to the API :) It doesn't need to be much, but I think you should show and describe how the API is changing. Some operator or user reading this spec would rightfully be confused to see a spec that says "add/change the api" and then have no description of the actual change in the "API impact" section :)

I'm not sure if there's any API impact in this case. IIUC we've a defined set of attributes for the response for every store i.e. "id", "type", "description", "properties" etc[1]
We already return values for "id", "type" and "description" for every store configured and return an empty JSON object {} for the "properties" field of stores other than RBD.
With this new implementation, we will now be returning the "properties" value for other stores but the attribute "properties" still exists in the current API response and that won't change and i don't consider that to be an API change, thoughts?

[1] https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/glance-specs/specs/yoga/approved/glance/expose-store-specific-info.html#rest-api-impact

No security impact? Are there no things exposed from these that are potentially sensitive? How is exposing the filesystem_store_dir not a potential security problem?

I think at least documenting that this is supposed to be admin-only is the answer, but it needs to be here, IMHO.

You can add here something like;

It is recommended to restrict this API call for admin users only.

A question you should address: I believe all the info you are planning to return is contained in the glance config, so this call will not impact glance_store (that is, you are *not* requiring glance_store drivers to implement a 'get_store_properties' function that returns some kind of store_properties dict).  I think this is important because it means you won't be returning any kind of info that requires a call out to the backend to get values of properties of the store that aren't configured on the glance side.  Which is fine, I just think you should be clear here about the scope of this effort.

> A question you should address: I believe all the info you are planning to return is contained in the glance config, so this call will not impact glance_store (that is, you are *not* requiring glance_store drivers to implement a 'get_store_properties' function that returns some kind of store_properties dict).

Right, the initial idea was to have glance store changes to return store properties but i think Abhishek pointed out that we already have a method "get_store_from_store_identifier" which returns a glance store backend object containing all the configured properties so we just went in with the glance side implementation.

> I think this is important because it means you won't be returning any kind of info that requires a call out to the backend to get values of properties of the store that aren't configured on the glance side.  Which is fine, I just think you should be clear here about the scope of this effort.

I've some confusion here, we require a call to backend ("get_store_from_store_identifier") but we don't need any implementation on glance store side for it (since it's already there). /COMMIT_MSG.message:
To complete the commit log it might be useful to reference the commit that introduced the phys_port_name support. Something like

---
This change essentially makes commit 4887b656c2 [udev: net_id: add support for phys_port_name attribute (#4506)] from systemd upstream togglable by enabling "vSTX7_0" naming. See [https://github.com/systemd/systemd/pull/4506]
---

As a reviewer the upstream discussions for both the systemd and kernel changes provide useful insight.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: Bizarre patch numbering scheme in use.

Until a story can be done to support moving to newer device naming scheme in the later versions of systemd, this type of approach to keep the device names the same between CentOS and Debian is required, especially for handling the upgrade scenario.
Verified in the HW lab we observed the issue.

Hi Dan,

Great explanation! I was looking purely at the code, and I appear to have misinterpreted it. Thank you for your patience with me.

Vefa

Overall logic looks ok.

----
Used v217 by mistake. Line numbers don't change. Between 217 and 219 there were format update and one str function replaced by other, we can consider them equivalent for now. Will update to v219 notation.

Indeed there are some small differences between upstream 219 and CentOS 219(219+)
Short description is: dev_port vs dev_id usage. To me it seems in 247 it is better understood that dev_id is almost always 0(with the exception of some infiniband), code was restructured for the happy path. Instead of looking for dev_id>0, then dev_port, it is now looking for dev_port, then dev_id if dev_port is 0 and infiniband.

Not worried about this, but if you feel we want to rearrange the search to 219+ style, we can do that.

-------------
The startswith vs streq for a specific length: String equal for a specific length has the same functionality as string starts with something.

Loop breaks:
1) there is a loop break out of FOREACH_DIRENT_ALL(even if on 219 is not called FOREACH_DIRENT_ALL) on both versions, when hotplug_slot > 0. This means just don't parse more /sys/bus/pci/slots/ entries, because we already found a match somewhere. If no match was found hotplug_slot will be -1, names->pci_slot will not be populated later.

2)
In this commit an extra search for the parent pci devices was introduced: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/9009d3b5c3b6d191be69215736be77583e0f23f9

So instead of doing a single search, it does multiple passes. [I'm assuming just 1 more, because I'm assuming there is just 1 parent, but I'm not a pci expert. This assumption doesn't matter, there can be multiple passes anyway.]

We do want hotplug_slot to be reset to 0. First it will break the FOREACH_DIRENT_ALL because it found a match. Then it will break the while loop because it found a match(hotplug_slot>=0). Since hotplug_slot=0 (hotplug_slot<=0) it will be the equivalent of v219, it will tell it not to populate names->pci_slot.
Note: hotplug_slot=0 can only be achieved when parsing a parent.

Here I'm assuming from a slot perspective only PCI bridges are parents, which can be confirmed by a PCI expert.

Better rephrased
'''If there is no parent search, this code is dead.''' += '''If it is looking at the leaf, this code is dead as the leaf is not a bridge.'''

---

Also showing some input for is_pci_bridge function, if that was a concern.

net pci, leaf, sc00 -> 00 doesn't match 04, not a bridge
/sys/devices/pci0000:36/0000:36:01.0/0000:38:00.0/0000:39:03.0/0000:3a:00.0/modalias
pci:v00008086d000037D1sv00001590sd00000247bc02sc00i00

brigdge pci, parents, sc04 -> 04 matches 04, is a bridge
cat /sys/devices/pci0000:36/0000:36:01.0/0000:38:00.0/0000:39:03.0/modalias
pci:v00008086d000037C5sv0000BEEFsd0000DEADbc06sc04i00
cat /sys/devices/pci0000:36/0000:36:01.0/0000:38:00.0/modalias
pci:v00008086d000037C0sv0000BEEFsd0000DEADbc06sc04i00
cat /sys/devices/pci0000:36/0000:36:01.0/modalias
pci:v00008086d00002031sv00001590sd000000EAbc06sc04i00

Hey, Vefa, I'll try to rephrase and use a real example.


udev will look for slot addresses [1], and compare with the pci device path [3]. For completion showing [3] is a leaf, net type pci device: [2].


[1]:
'''
cat /sys/bus/pci/slots/1/address
0000:64:00
'''
[2]: /sys/devices/pci0000:64/0000:64:00.0/0000:65:00.0/net/ens1f0np0/
[3]: /sys/devices/pci0000:64/0000:64:00.0/0000:65:00.0
[4]: /sys/devices/pci0000:64/0000:64:00.0/



In v219+ it will only look at [3], see 0000:65:00 not equal with 0000:64:00. It won't do anything else. hotplug_slot will be -1.


Later this introduced the logic to search parents: https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/9009d3b5c3b6d191be69215736be77583e0f23f9

It will also search the parent of [3], which is [4], see 0000:64:00 equals with 0000:64:00, and return the hotplug_slot = value_here (from /sys/bus/pci/slots/<value_here>/address).
[For out CentOS compatibility this is undesired.]

A flag to disable this was introduced(NAMING_BRIDGE_NO_SLOT):
https://github.com/systemd/systemd/commit/2c8ec0095e6fd2e72879d4915ff8a9e5c0664d0b
Note that reset of hotplug_slot to 0 happens only for parents. [4] is a bridge. [3] is not, each time the search will start from a leaf which is not a bridge.
If there is no parent search, this code is dead.

So NAMING_BRIDGE_NO_SLOT flag has meaning only for parent searches and aligns with old CentOS behavior, it will allow the result of initial search on the the leaf(net pci) to pass through.
No worries 😊. I appreciate the concern, we now have clear examples here.

Hi,

I am setting -1 as the code review score not as a negative review, but mainly to indicate that there is a discussion that I would like to reach consensus on.

Thank you,

Vefa

Need some comment on the backoff mechanism.

The wait should be an idempotent random number i.e. different wait time for each subcloud but the same wait time * backoff factor for subsequent retries of the same subcloud.
pool is now created within the 'for' loop?

largest wait time is 495 seconds? based on present values : 15*2**5 + random(0,15)  ... would be helpful to comment on largest value accordingly; and which system timeouts may be affected when this value is further increased

idx = 2
wait_before_retry (max) = 15 * 2 ** (3 - 2 + 1) + 15 = 75s

idx = 1
wait_before_retry (max) = 15 * 2 ** (3 - 1 + 1) + 15 = 135s

New implementation the potential wait (total) is 210s. Old implementation, potential wait (total) is only 30s

No, the old implementation is 60s in total. It is potentially longer than the old implementation, but it's an extreme scenario and I think it is still acceptable. I care more about the minimum wait time in the 1st round, it's better to be identical to the old implementation which is the 30s.

specs/zuul_job_reporting.rst.message:
Looking at how ARA works today, I would like to see the current callback plugin be more generic.  For example, rather then writing the data directly to sqlite, we could use something like mqtt, gearman, or fedmsg. This allows use to start scaling out logging operations much link we do with our logstash workers today.

I understand the launcher will need ansible plugins, but data processing should be pushed out to another service.

So right now the database interactions are generic enough as they abstracted through SQLAlchemy which means other relational databases (MySQL, PostreSQL) can also be used without any hassle.

I have not yet considered another mechanism of recording/publishing data as recorded by the callback.
I would need to think about this one, not that I disagree about it - just that it'd be a fundamental architectural change in how data is sent/received/used.

As far as where the data processing is involved, it can be done from anywhere that has access to the database (sqlite, mysql, etc.).
We can opt for a "centralized" aggregated instance, a bit like openstack-health -- but the scale at which OpenStack operates has definitely not been well tested and proven.
We could do something in the middle, perhaps -- store the data in the logs and generate the report asynchronously by retrieving the data like openstack-health does.

I understand this is how ARA works today, and this is fine.  I don't think ARA should be at the core of zuul, meaning touching zuul-launcher.  I think what we should do with zuul, is find a way to archive runs of ansible in a generic way that ARA, and other tools, can generate reports from it.

Obviously, I think this should work more along the lines of how we handle logs with our logstash-workers, I think clarkb might be better suited on the technical side.

One method I've been thinking of is, we add a generic call back plugin to collect the information we need.  Then, instead of writing to sqlalchemy, we use something like fedmsg (https://github.com/henrysher/fedora-infra-ansible/blob/master/callback_plugins/fedmsg_callback.py) or some other bus. Then, on the far side, ARA lives to process the data.

This is because, our zuul-launchers might not live in the same control plan as ARA or even database.  Something like using a bus (eg: firehose.o.o) gives other things the ability to access the data too.

Note, I mention fedmsg only because we are considering adding a reporter direction into zuul for it.  It would be great if ansible would also report to it too.
This isn't really different from the console log is it? Is there extra exposure in what ARA reports?

I would like to keep the requirements for zuul itself (ie, whatever we need to run on the launcher) minimal.  If ara grows requirements such as these, we should consider splitting it into a package for the callback plugin and one for the webapp.

Almost, but not quite: this is what it needs to look like:

    bases:
      - build-on:
          - name: ubuntu
            channel: "20.04"
            architectures:
              - amd64
        run-on:
          - name: ubuntu
            channel: "20.04"
            architectures: [amd64, s390x, ppc64el, arm64]

This means: "build on 20.04 amd64 architecture", and advertise the charm as "runs on 20.04 amd64, s390x, ppc64el and arm64 architectures on the charmhub".  i.e. build once on amd64 and run "everywhere we care about."

> Patch Set 1:
> 
> Based on what I understood about the feedback we got from legal counsel, this seems like an unnecessarily pedantic application of that feedback. Using the terms adjacent to one another in headlines, marketing collateral and the like is the real concern. Descriptive use in technical prose about release process doesn't rise to that level of attention, and so we ought to be free to use whatever flows best within the document here. Maybe avoid putting the words "tick" and "tock" next to one another in page titles, it doesn't seem like this specific change is warranted.
> 
> If you're still concerned and want to clear this document with the foundation staff, Jonathan indicated to me that he would be happy to provide more direct feedback on it.

Sure, What I heard from Wes is not only using them together in page title but in anywhere. Like this resolution used it (which I am changing now) and same was published in few site/articles which is problematic. for example: https://techcrunch.com/2022/03/30/openstackl-aunches-yoga-its-25th-release/

From that I think we need to avoid using them together in documentation, page title or anywhere public facing documentation.

But let's add them in review to confirm it or if anything more we need to fix.

Agree -- the issue is in using the two words close together. Whether an hyphen or a comma separates them is really irrelevant.

Which is the core of the issue: it's quite difficult to explain the scheme (the regular cycling through two states) without putting the two words next together... This is why some suggested to use a completely different set of names to convey the same sense of regularity.

I understand that major/minor has extra baggage, spring/fall has a hemisphere problem. But maybe names like odd/even, day/night, ping/pong, whiff/whaff can convey the same idea without creating a potential issue down the road. You can upgrade between two ping releases, or from ping to pong and pong to ping.

I am not a huge fan of tick tock or ping pong.  Do I have a better suggestion?  No.  So, I think we are probably best taking the feedback on tick tock and going to ping pong as I think it communicates, as best we can, what we are trying to do with our release cycles.
LOL lawyers, but.. sure :D
Looks good to me.
not sure if Wes using gerrit as I did not find him.

You mean to use "Skip-Level Upgrade Release Process (SLURP)" in documentation like here ? (that is why it will e easy to ref ?) and use SLU in the release page or SLURP?

OpenStack 2023.1 AA (SLU) or OpenStack 2023.1 AA (SLURP)?

I am also thinking if that is ok from communicating the releasenote things, for example, "Communicate the non-SLURP release deprecated/upgradeable release notes to SLURP release too" I think that should be ok. I mean when tock was recognized by 'tock' and now it can be recognized by not having "SLU" tag in that.

> You mean to use "Skip-Level Upgrade Release Process (SLURP)" in documentation like here ? (that is why it will e easy to ref ?) and use SLU in the release page or SLURP?

I meant "SLU" is not as easy to pronounce or say as something like "SLURP" which is more like a word.

> OpenStack 2023.1 AA (SLU) or OpenStack 2023.1 AA (SLURP)?

The latter. I just added two letters to your suggestion to make it easier to say as a word, but otherwise fine with that proposal.

> I am also thinking if that is ok from communicating the releasenote things, for example, "Communicate the non-SLURP release deprecated/upgradeable release notes to SLURP release too" I think that should be ok. I mean when tock was recognized by 'tock' and now it can be recognized by not having "SLU" tag in that.

Yep, I understand and I also think that's okay. I think it's slightly nicer to say "tock" or "pong" compared to "non-SLURP" or "not a SLURP". However, for the people that say they can't remember which is which, "SLURP" and "non-SLURP" will likely be much easier to remember which is the special release, vs. "tick" or "ping".

If we do that, perhaps Skip-Level Upgrade Release Process (SLURP) so that it's easy to reference.

I also thought about "fast/slow" and "long/short". The benefit of choosing something less "binary" is that we can alter that cadence (i.e. more releases between SLURP releases) in the future if we want.

I think it's pretty clear from this and other naming discussions going on at the moment that we're not going to please everyone with whatever we choose :/
cool, sounds good to me.

ping and pong have very similar characteristics to tick and tock, and also share the same second letter, so it should be very easy to convert documentation and mental state. So, that'd be my vote of everything I've heard so far as an alternative.

I did not mean to separate them with commas but with quotes I think they are used as separate like 'tick' 'tock' are not same as 'tick tock' but if they are same thing from legal perspective then ok.

as we need to use them as tag and not a name as such how about using 'SLU' (Skip Level Upgradable) for tick(current name) release and do not use anything for tock release? and in documentation like this resolution of anywhere we can use 'SLU' and 'non-SLU' as name?

For example: release page/any other doc can tag the release like:
- OpenStack 2023.1 AA (SLU)
- OpenStack 2023.2 BB
- OpenStack 2024.1 CC (SLU)

self.filter_conf is *always* the starting point that is updated by any loaded conf - previously loaded config file value is forgotten unless included in config file on next reload.

-1: This is creating the multipath.conf file, an appropriate name is necessary. e.g. "_ensure_multipath_conf_exists"

-1: This will replace existing values if /ect/multipath.conf already exists.

For example existing multipath.conf could have "find_multipaths" set to "no", because detection is faster if all volumes are going to be multipathed, but with this command it will change the current configuration to wait until there is a second device (or if it's the second time we attach the same volume and it was multipathed before).

In my opinion conditioning the creation of the file to the file not existing should suffice.

Keep in mind that it's a deployment ramdisk, i.e. a controlled environment. The configuration file cannot just appear.

But yeah, we can check it nonetheless.

nit: This comment is misleading

The comment here says "kernel to actually do the needful and identify paths", but  "multipath -ll" only collects available information from multiple sources to present it in a nice and organized way.

That is different from identify existing paths (devices) in the system, checking them against known multipathed WWID devices and other paths, and creating the DM for the multipath.  Which, iirc, is done via udev events/rules.

I would suggest the commit log be expanded to describe the usecase. As it is I am not entirely sure what I am reviewing as it is not entirely clear.
For example: There are more than 100 source packages, but we just want to build package NTP, then all source packages that ntp build depend on will also been selected and build.

At the very begining, dsc_depend is designed to make the build order of inputed dsc file list. In original realization, its input is just a list file that contains all dsc files that need to be build. That means it only fit for `build-pkg -a`, not fit for `build-pkg -p xxx`.
While this review add an input called "target_pkgs"(list or set), it contains all target dsc packages. Now it has two inputs: a list file contains all possible dsc files, a list/set of dsc files that we need to build. For example, we have 100 source packages but just want to build package A and B. We can let dsc_depend check to see if there are other source packages(C, D...) need to be build firstly, and then give us the build order.
Thanks for the feedback.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This is an opendev gate issue since the nodes use unbound?  The problem being that unbound isn't responding before devstack starts?

I'm not sure we've seen this in other jobs, but that's probably because after node boot regular jobs do a lot of pre-work that would hide any quick startup race or ordering issues.

If that is the problem, perhaps we should be looking more closely at the nodepool side -- it seems likely the systemd service bringing this up should not let boot progress until unbound is listening properly.  It not doing that is more likely an oversight in unbound installation than desired behavior.

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I think we should have an upper bound on the retries.

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> Ade Lee wrote:
> 
> > Whatever sets up the unbound server shouldn't proceed till
> > we know DNS resolution works, to prevent race conditions.
> 
> It's really more that the init shouldn't treat the system as up until DNS resolution is working (unbound is set up before the reboot, it's the init at boot currently treating unbound's start completion as optional that contributes to this problem).

To be concrete, we do publish the images @

https://nb0<1|2|3>.opendev.org/images/

and most of the unbound setup is done @ https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/src/branch/master/nodepool/elements/nodepool-base/finalise.d/89-boot-settings

I *think* we are just setting up unbound config and then using the service file from the distro

I found at least one bug that seems to describe this, e.g. https://github.com/NLnetLabs/unbound/issues/296

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> Dr. Jens Harbott wrote:
> 
> > IMO this doesn't belong here. Devstack should be able to expect a working host
> > setup. If you reboot the host in the fips playbook, put that check there.
> 
> The questions then become: What criteria should fips-setup use to determine when a host is "working" after reboot? If the definition of "working" from the perspective of fips-setup in zuul-jobs is also "I can resolve records via DNS" then what DNS record(s) should it attempt to query?

The answer to the last question should be the same as the answer proposed here. But I also agree with ianw's comment that there may be an even deeper issue with the way we set up unbound vs. system startup.

> Patch Set 3:
> 
> Dr. Jens Harbott wrote:
> 
> > The answer to the last question should be the same as the answer proposed here.
> 
> With my zuul-jobs reviewer hat on, I'm not sure having a generic role hard-code an assumption (or even default to it) that systems should try resolving opendev.org is a good idea. At a minimum, it would need some escape hatch for jobs being run in environments where nodes may not have access to a fully open recursive resolver, either to skip the check or substitute an alternative record which is known to be resolvable by those nodes... but beyond that, should the fips-setup role necessarily even depend on having working DNS resolution?

Seems to me that the fips-setup-role has really nothing to do with whether DNS resolution is working or not.  The only reason it comes up here is because the role happens to reboot the node.

To Jen's point though, devstack has every right to expect a "working system" to begin with - and while having a check here would be very useful and informative, we don't check all the many other things that make up a "working system".

Ian's suggestion makes the most sense to me.  Whatever sets up the unbound server shouldn't proceed till we know DNS resolution works, to prevent race conditions.

FYI, the test patch shows this works:
https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/654645cad8d444c48de7595ed5f5b1c2/log/job-output.txt#2062

It required one retry (5 second interval) before the DNS resolved.
IMO this doesn't belong here. Devstack should be able to expect a working host setup. If you reboot the host in the fips playbook, put that check there.

I feel the opposite. Currently if DNS isn't working, devstack continues to run until it can't find a package. This error, that a package isn't found is misleading (bad mirror, bad repo, etc.). I think it's better to have an explicit test that calls out the true problem early.

stack.sh.message:
I think there is an easier way to do this.

nslookup -retry=60 opendev.org

This will give 60 connect attempts with a 5 second delay (default), so it will try for about five minutes and give up.
